moves.1. c4 e5 2. e4 d6 3. d4 exd4 4. Qxd4: I decide it's worth swapping pawns, creating some space.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Qd3 Nb4: I give the queen the runaround
moves.13. h3 O-O-O 14. Ne2 Nb8: I now have a three pronged attack on e4...
moves.15. f3: ...but my opponent is wise to this.
moves.18. Kc2 Qe5: ...but have no option but to again retreat.
moves.19. f4 Qe7 20. a4 Bxe4: I push the bishop forward, removing the pawn...
moves.21. Rhg1: ...but my opponent declines to take it...
moves.23. Qf5+ Qe6: ...but have to put up some defence...
moves.24. Qxe6+ fxe6: ...but still maintain a reasonable pawn structure.
moves.25. cxd5 Rxd5: I regain my one pawn advantage...
moves.27... Nd5: I bring a knight into play...
moves.30... Nc7 31. Nc3 Be7 32. g4 Rd8: Now I contest the open d-file, as the king cannot move into it...
moves.33. Rxd8+ Kxd8: ...and get the exchange I was looking for. Now with the rooks gone, things get really interesting...
Now I have a two pawn advantage.
moves.39... Bd6 40. Ng3 Bxg3: I decide to take the knight, as the bishop can only cover black squares.
moves.41. Bxg3 Ne3: No escape for the pawn. See how isolated pawns fall quite easily? That explains 38. ... exf5.
moves.43. Kc3 g5 44. Bf6 h6 45. Kb3 Nd4+: I give the king the runaround...
moves.48. Kc3 Ne4+: ...and again, splitting him and the bishop.
